summary: This document is an email chain from November 2020 among U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) staff regarding the privilege review and processing of data extracted from Jeffrey Epstein's electronic devices (phones and iPads). It details the technical process of generating redacted reports, withholding potentially privileged materials, and meeting discovery deadlines.

persons.name: Enrique Santos
persons.context: U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) staff member involved in the technical process of handling and copying data from Epstein's devices for the privilege review.

persons.name: Darren Indyke
persons.context: Mentioned as having a chat with Jeffrey Epstein that was removed as potentially privileged (PP) from the data review.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The deceased financier whose electronic devices (phones and iPads) are the subject of the data extraction and privilege review process detailed in the emails.

connections.description: A chat between Epstein and Indyke was flagged and removed as potentially privileged material during the data review.

events.title: Discovery Deadline
events.description: A tight discovery deadline mentioned as the reason for urgency in completing the responsiveness review of Epstein device data.

events.title: Drive Copying and Shipping
events.description: A hard drive containing data from Epstein's devices was copied and shipped via FedEx to a team member for the privilege review.

keyFacts: The document details an internal U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) process in late 2020 for reviewing data from multiple Jeffrey Epstein devices (phones/iPads coded 1B71, 1B72, 1869, 1884, 1883, 1867, 1868) for privilege and responsiveness.
Significant volumes of potentially privileged (PP) material were withheld: 1107 emails from one device, 169 PP emails and one PP chat (with Darren Indyke) from another, and 93 PP emails from a third.
The review was under a tight deadline, with a need to finish responsiveness tagging by November 5, 2020, to prepare for a November 9, 2020, production deadline.

The correspondence reveals logistical and technical challenges in handling the large data sets, including network issues and the need to copy files to local drives to avoid crashing the office network.
